compounddef.innerclass: shyft::timeseries::d_ref_t< T, typename enable_if< is_shared_ptr< T >::value >::type >
shyft::timeseries::is_ts< bin_op< A, B, O, TA > >

briefdescription.para: the point value represents the value at the specific time (or centered around that time),typically linear accessor
the point value represents the average of the interval, typically stair-case start of step accessor
Enumerates how points are mapped to f(t)

detaileddescription.para: If there is a point_ts, this determines how we would draw f(t). Average values are typically staircase-start-of step, a constant over the interval for which the average is computed. State-in-time values are typically POINT_INSTANT_VALUES; and we could as an approximation draw a straight line between the points.

briefdescription.para: point a and b are considered equal if same time t and value-diff less than EPS
d_ref function to d_ref object or shared_ptr

detaileddescription.para: The T d_ref(T) template to return a ref or const ref to T, if T is shared_ptr<T> or just T

briefdescription.para: d_ref_t template to rip out T of shared_ptr<T> or T if T specified

detaileddescription.para: time_shift function, to ease syntax and usability

briefdescription.para: hint_based search to eliminate binary-search in irregular time-point series.

detaileddescription.para:
utilizing the fact that most access are periods, sequential, so the average_xxx functions can utilize this, and keep the returned index as a hint for the next request for average_xxx value.
S
a point ts source, must have .get(i) ->point, and .size(), and .index_of(t)->size_t
source
a point ts source as described above
p
utcperiod for which we search a start point <= p.start
i
the start-of-search hint, could be -1, then ts.index_of(p.start) is used to figure out the ix.
lowerbound index or npos if not found
We should specialize this for sources with computed time-axis to improve speed

memberdef.argsstring: (const S &source, const utcperiod &p, size_t &last_idx, utctimespan &tsum, bool linear=true)
memberdef.name: accumulate_value

briefdescription.para: accumulate_value provides a projection/interpretation of the values of a pointsource on to a time-axis as provided. This includes interpolation and true average, linear between points and nan-handling semantics. In addition the Accessor allows fast sequential access to these values using clever caching of the last position used in the underlying point source. The time axis and point source can be of any type as listed above as long as the basic type requirement as described below are satisfied.

parameterdescription.para:
point source, must provide:
.size() const -> number of points in the source
.index_of(utctime tx) const -> return lower bound index or -1 for the supplied tx
.get(size_t i) const -> return the i'th point (t,v)
of type S
the period [start,end) on time-axis, the range where we will accumulate/integrate the f(t)
of the last time point used on the source, updated after each call.
out, the sum of time under non-nan areas of the curve

simplesect.para: double, the area under the non-nan areas of the curve, specified by tsum ref-parameter

memberdef.argsstring: (const S &source, const utcperiod &p, size_t &last_idx, bool linear=true)
memberdef.name: average_value

briefdescription.para: average_value provides a projection/interpretation of the values of a pointsource on to a time-axis as provided. This includes interpolation and true average, linear between points and nan-handling semantics. In addition the Accessor allows fast sequential access to these values using clever caching of the last position used in the underlying point source. The time axis and point source can be of any type as listed above as long as the basic type requirement as described below are satisfied.

parameterdescription.para:
point source, must provide:
.size() const -> number of points in the source
.index_of(utctime tx) const -> return lower bound index or -1 for the supplied tx
.get(size_t i) const -> return the i'th point (t,v)
of type S
the period [start,end) on time-axis
of the last time point used on the source, updated after each call.

simplesect.para: double, the value at the as true average of the specified period

briefdescription.para: Discrete l2 norm of input time series treated as a vector: (sqrt(sum(x_i)))

simplesect.para: only used for debug/printout during calibration

parameterdescription.para: the accessor type that implement: -#: .size() number of elements the accessor can provide -#: .value(i) value of the i'th element in the accessor

briefdescription.para: Nash Sutcliffe model effiency coefficient based goal function http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NashE2%80%93Sutcliffe_model_efficiency_coefficient.

simplesect.para: throws runtime exception if supplied arguments differs in .size() or .size()==0
if obs. is a constant, we get 1/0

parameterdescription.para: a ts accessor for the observed ts ( support .size() and double .value(i))
a ts accessor for the observed ts ( support .size() and double .value(i))
contains the observed values for the model
contains the (simulated) model output values

simplesect.para: 1- E, given E=n.s, i.e. 0 is best performance > 0 .. +oo is less good performance.

memberdef.argsstring: (const TSA1 &observed_ts, const TSA2 &model_ts, double s_r, double s_a, double s_b)
memberdef.name: kling_gupta_goal_function

briefdescription.para: KLING-GUPTA Journal of Hydrology 377 (2009) 8091, page 83, formula (10), where shorthands are a=alpha, b=betha, q =sigma, u=my, s=simulated, o=observed

parameterdescription.para: template class like dlib::running_scalar_covariance<double> that supports .add(x), hten mean_x|_y stddev_x|_y,correlation
time-series accessor that supports .size(), .value(i)
time-series accessor that supports .size(), .value(i)
the time-series that is the target, observed true value
the time-series that is the model simulated/calculated ts
the kling gupta scale r factor (weight the correlation of goal function)
the kling gupta scale a factor (weight the relative average of the goal function)
the kling gupta scale b factor (weight the relative standard deviation of the goal function)

simplesect.para: EDs= 1-KGEs, that have a minimum at zero

detaileddescription.para: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percentile NIST definitions, we use R7, R and excel seems more natural.. http://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/handbook/prc/section2/prc262.htm calculate percentile using full sort.. works nice for a larger set of percentiles.

memberdef.argsstring: (const ta_t &ta, const std::vector< ts_t > &ts_list, const std::vector< int > &percentiles, size_t min_t_steps=1000)
memberdef.name: calculate_percentiles

briefdescription.para: calculate specified percentiles for supplied list of time-series over the specified time-axis

detaileddescription.para: Percentiles for a set of timeseries, over a time-axis we would like to : percentiles_timeseries = calculate_percentiles(ts-id-list,time-axis,percentiles={0,25,50,100}) done like this 1..m ts-id, time-axis( start,dt, n), read 1..m ts into memory percentiles specified is np result is percentiles_timeseries accessor "accumulate" on time-axis to dt, using stair-case or linear between points create result vector[1..n] (the time-axis dimension) where each element is vector[1..np] (for each timestep, we get the percentiles for each timestep_i in timeaxis for each tsa_i: accessors(timeaxis,ts) samplevector[timestep_i].emplace_back( tsa_i(time_step_i) ) percentiles_timeseries[timestep_i]= calculate_percentiles(..)

memberdef.argsstring: (const ts_t &ts, const calendar &cal, utctime t, utctimespan dt, size_t n, utctime t0, time_shift_func &&make_time_shift_fx)
memberdef.name: partition_by

briefdescription.para: partition_by convert a time-series into a vector of time-shifted partitions of ts with a common time-reference

detaileddescription.para: The partitions are simply specified by calendar, delta_t (could be symbolic, like YEAR:MONTH:DAY) and n. To make yearly partitions, just pass calendar::YEAR as dt. The t-parameter set the start-time point in the source-time-series, like 1930.09.01 The t0-parameter set the common start-time of the new partitions

The typical usage will be to use this function to partition years into a vector with e.g. 80 years, where we can do statistics, percentiles to compare and see the different effects of yearly season variations. Note that the function is more general, allowing any periodic partition, like daily, weekly, monthly etc. to study any pattern or statistics that might be periodic by the partition pattern.
For exposure to python, additional preparation of the partitions could be useful like .average( timeaxis(t0,deltahours(1),365*24)) to make all with an equal-sized time-axis

parameterdescription.para: return type time-series, equal to the return-type of the time_shift_func()
a callable type, that accepts ts_t and utctimespan as input and return rts_t
time-series type that goes into the partition algorithm
of type ts_t
specifies the calendar to be used for possible calendar and time-zone semantic operations
specifies the time-point to start, e.g. 1930.09.01
specifies the calendar-semantic length of the partitions, e.g. calendar::YEAR|MONTH|DAY|WEEK
number of partitions, e.g. if you would have 80 yearly partitions, set n=80
the common time-reference for the partitions, e.g. 2016.09.01 for 80 yearly partitions 1930.09.01 to 2010.09.01
a callable that accepts const ts_t& and utctimespan and returns a time-shifted ts of type rts_t

simplesect.para: the partition vector, std::vector<rts_t> of size n, where each partition ts have its start-value at t0
t0 must align with multiple delta-t from t, e.g. if t is 1930.09.1, then t0 must have a pattern like YYYY.09.01

parameterdescription.para: if t0 is not aligned with t, see note above.
